image.altText: Emergency workers dressed in hi-vis yellow attend to an exploded house

props.synopsis: An investigation into the house explosion in Sydney's west on Saturday is looking at whether a gas leak was to blame, as an expert says leaks can be difficult to detect but can cause major damage.

title.children: A gas leak potentially destroyed a Sydney home and killed a person inside. Here's what to do when you smell gas

image.altText: Woman in high-vis orange jacket holding a teddy bear wearing sunglasses

props.synopsis: Patrizia Cassaniti will carry her son's ashes inside a toy bear at parliament today, with long-awaited industrial manslaughter legislation to be introduced.

title.children: Patrizia's son died calling her name. Now she's getting justice for victims of workplace accidents

image.altText: Man bathed in blue light on Tekno Train looking at the view of Sydney CBD out the window

props.synopsis: Vivid's Tekno Train gives passengers a glimpse of the historic, and usually inaccessible Lavender Bay line — and a hint of "what the future could be".

title.children: Rave train trip on derelict Sydney track reveals perfect spot for a New York-style High Line

image.altText: Xini was born in Beijing on May 30, 1989.

props.synopsis: On the night of the Tiananmen Square massacre, a new mother witnessed the influx of casualties in the emergency room while her propaganda artist husband was in Sydney. Thirty-five years later, the couple reveal how the brutal crackdown has impacted the rest of their lives.

title.children: Propaganda artist Shen Jiawei was a true believer. The Tiananmen Square massacre changed his path forever

image.altText: Man leaning on balcony railing with coffee cup, looking out to sea, small wallaby marsupial behind him, coastal background

props.synopsis: Ron Taylor lives most of the year wandering around his island home in solitude, living off-grid away from the pressures of the rat race. It's a "great lifestyle".

title.children: Ron could be a modern-day Gilligan living on his isolated island. But he has no desire to be rescued

props.synopsis: The Victorian Department of Education faces several lawsuits from survivors who were sexually abused by a teacher the department knowingly moved to other schools after fielding complaints of abuse.

title.children: Serial predator Arthur Eaton 'fooled' everyone with a guide dog puppy and almost became teacher of the year

image.altText: Light brown French bulldog puppy lying on bright yellow floor.

props.synopsis: Australia has one of the highest pet ownership rates in the world. But are we being the best pet parents possible? Or do we need to rethink how we breed, buy and care for our animals?

title.children: Wildlife scientist Ellie says there are some dogs 'we just shouldn't have'. Here's why

image.altText: Ali Syed walks down a busy street

props.synopsis: From higher education to fast food, Legal Aid says wage theft is "everywhere" in Australia.

title.children: Ali complained to his boss about being underpaid. Then they fired him

image.altText: Four aboriginal men walk in nature.

props.synopsis: This year, I have spent several months with about a dozen former prisoners at a halfway house in Sydney called Rainbow Lodge. It was a sobering experience, and I'm now thoroughly disabused of my naivety.

title.children: Australia can fix its broken prison system like Norway did. But first, we must face up to the facts

image.altText: Woman looks at laptop screen.

props.synopsis: The Fair Work Commission has been careful not to trigger another interest rate rise with its latest minimum and award wage increase, but a pay rise barely keeping up with inflation does little to ease the pressure on household budgets either.

title.children: Reserve Bank boffins will be happy with Fair Work's award pay increase, but will workers share their joy?

image.altText: Madi - a young woman with blue-green hair, standing in front of a tree

props.synopsis: The rental crisis not only brings you down, but research suggests it can affect your very sense of self and decisions you make.

title.children: 'I feel like I've failed': How the rental crisis warps your sense of the future

image.altText: A woman soccer player is wrapped in a large cloak made of kangaroo skin by a famous Aboriginal sports icon

props.synopsis: As the Matildas' longest-serving goalkeeper and proud Noongar woman, Lydia Williams has ushered through a new era of Australian sport, both on and off the field.

title.children: 'It's everything': Lydia Williams leaves the Matildas as one of its greatest legacies

image.altText: Packets of Tim Tam biscuits on a shelf, with a price tag saying $11.70

props.synopsis: The cost of living has increased more sharply in regional areas than in the cities, with some outback residents paying double for essential goods like food and fuel. Now the federal government is coming up with a plan to try to level the playing field, but will it work?

title.children: Could you afford to live in a town where Tim Tams cost $11.70?

image.altText: A woman sits holding a piece of paper with her head in her other hand, looking stressed.

props.synopsis: An ASIC survey has found rising levels of financial hardship among Australians, who say they'd rather sell off assets before they ask their lenders for assistance.

title.children: Millions of Australians facing financial difficulty, according to ASIC survey

image.altText: Chloe rests in a hospital bed with bandages around her head.

props.synopsis: At just two-years-old, Chloe suffered two types of stroke — now she's learning to walk on her own.

title.children: When Chloe had brain surgery, her parents sat through 'the worst seven hours of our lives'

image.altText: A woman sitting in a tractor

props.synopsis: When farmer Melissa Smyth's not out on her property on the South Australian-Victorian border, she can be found painting or creating mosaics in her shed. Her new-found passion for art was sparked by what's known as the Pinnaroo Project.

title.children: This farming town has found a way to reduce depression and improve wellbeing in the bush

image.altText: Indian prime minister Narendra Modi, wearing a white shirt and orange scarf, holds his hands together in prayer

props.synopsis: If exit polls are correct, the strongman leader of the world's most populous country is on track for a record-equalling third consecutive term.

title.children: India's Modi eyes historic win in world's biggest election

image.altText: A close up of Greg Lynn standing in front of a body of water near some rocks.

props.synopsis: In a police interview played in court, accused murderer Greg Lynn details his account of how campers Russell Hill and Carol Clay's lives ended in Victoria's High Country.

title.children: 'What am I gonna do?': Pilot's panicked moments after campers' deaths detailed to court

image.altText: Sam Wallace holds the Super Netball trophy as streamers red and blue fly around her head

props.synopsis: The Swifts make a huge call to replace three-time club MVP Sam Wallace-Joseph with a 19-year-old shooter, the Aussie Diamonds squad announcement is close, and Lightning fail to execute the super shot against Fever.

title.children: Super Netball round-up — Wallace-Joseph dropped, Diamonds selection imminent, and the Lightning have super shot regrets

image.altText: A giant bird with an emu like body but a bald skin head like a giant turkey with a very large beak.

props.synopsis: Freshly discovered skulls of a giant prehistoric bird that lived in Australia until about 45,000 years ago reveal it had a "goose-like beak" and other aquatic adaptations.

title.children: Think regular geese are scary? Meet Australia's 230kg 'giga-goose'

image.altText: A few chairs and a table on a large patch of dirt in a rural community.

props.synopsis: The NT government has outlined its road map for Territorians to "learn to live with alcohol", meaning long-standing bans could soon be overturned.

title.children: Long-standing alcohol bans in remote NT communities could soon be overturned

image.altText: A woman sitting in a tractor

props.synopsis: When farmer Melissa Smyth's not out on her property on the South Australian-Victorian border, she can be found painting or creating mosaics in her shed. Her new-found passion for art was sparked by what's known as the Pinnaroo Project.

title.children: This farming town has found a way to reduce depression and improve wellbeing in the bush

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair in a tanned coat looking to her left.

props.synopsis: Donald Trump's apparent support for Julian Assange gives Joe Biden the ability to drop the extradition case against the WikiLeaks founder without "political blowback", Mr Assange's lawyer has told Q+A.

title.children: Julian Assange's lawyer says Donald Trump could give US President Joe Biden political cover to drop extradition case

image.altText: A man in his 50s in an orange suit stands on a stage, cloud and golden abstract structure in the b/g, his hands reaching togeth

props.synopsis: Back to Back Theatre has become one of Australia’s leading performing arts exports, all by making work that defies expectations.

title.children: This regional theatre company is changing the way people see disability, and taking over the world

image.altText: Alex de Minaur

props.synopsis: Australia's top-ranked men's tennis player Alex de Minaur will play in his first French Open quarterfinal after beating US Open champion Daniil Medvedev in four sets at Roland Garros.

title.children: 'Complete shock': De Minaur into his first French Open quarterfinal after fightback against Russian star

image.altText: A Toyota logo sits on a blue glass window display in grey writing with a car behind it

props.synopsis: Toyota — the world's biggest car manufacturer by volume — has admitted incorrectly testing airbag inflation and crash damage, with probes also underway into fuel efficiency and emissions data.

title.children: Japanese car manufacturers including Toyota admit manipulating safety testing data

image.altText: A woman in a dress at her graduation.

props.synopsis: Recent research shows more than half of 18 to 34-year-olds are delaying starting a family, blaming the current cost of living effects.

title.children: Why Australians like Sam aren't having children

image.altText: A court painting of Justin Laurens Stein in watercolours facing the side in a blue suit

props.synopsis: Justin Laurens Stein, 33, was called as a witness in his own defence after pleading not guilty to murdering nine-year-old schoolgirl Charlise Mutten in early 2022.

title.children: Man accused of murdering 9yo Charlise Mutten tells jury her mother shot schoolgirl dead

image.altText: Aerial shot of massive oil and gas rig in the Bass Strait off Victoria

props.synopsis: The company behind one of Australia's largest sources of oil and gas is planning the removal of about half of its platforms, but environmental groups are concerned it will create a toxic dump in Corner Inlet's wetland.

title.children: Concerns oil and gas rig removal from Bass Strait could pollute vulnerable Ramsar wetland

image.altText: Pom Pom dog with owner Scott McKinnon

props.synopsis: Anne Becroft and Scott McKinnon are among six witnesses giving evidence against Andrew Perez, who has pleaded not guilty to dozens of charges relating to allegations of fraud and carrying out residential building work without a licence or insurance.

title.children: Lithgow tornado victim testifies in fraud case against man who promised to rebuild her home

image.altText: Dr Max Mollenkopf smiles while standing on the footpath of a quiet Newcastle street on a bright, sunny day.

props.synopsis: Newcastle GP Max Mollenkopf says unnecessary appointments for medical certificates are wasting doctors' time.

title.children: Why this GP wants employers to stop asking for medical certificates

image.altText: Kellie Ann Carmichael

props.synopsis: Victorian woman Kellie Ann Carmichael went missing after leaving a hostel in the Blue Mountains in 2001. Her remains have been found in bushland near Katoomba, with an investigation underway.

title.children: Remains found in Blue Mountains confirmed to be woman who went missing 23 years ago

image.altText: Shorten looks serious, standing in profile, a painting just visible behind him.

props.synopsis: A speechwriter will be paid about $600,000 over two years to assist government minister Bill Shorten, despite Services Australia saying it has existing capacity to provide help.

title.children: Taxpayers set to fork out up to $600,000 for Bill Shorten's speechwriter over two years
